title: First International Forestry Exhibition
text:
The First International Forestry Exhibition was a <a href="world%27s%20fair">world's fair</a> held in 1884 was the first international gathering focusing on forestry. It was opened by the <a href="Schomberg%20Kerr%2C%209th%20Marquess%20of%20Lothian">Marquess of Lothian</a> and held in the grounds of <a href="Donaldson%27s%20College%23History">Donaldson's College</a>, <a href="Edinburgh">Edinburgh</a>, Scotland.
Background.
In the mid 19th century Britain faced reduced timber supplies from the Indian sub-continent (then <a href="British%20India">British India</a>) and had turned, under guidance from <a href="Hugh%20Cleghorn%20%28forester%29">Cleghorn</a> towards increased professionalism in forestry at home, and in India. In the late 19th century with Scotland, now established as the British centre for forestry and successful forestry education in established in <a href="Dehradun">Dehradun</a> this fair was held. Countries and colonies were being invited to produce papers and exhibit products for judgment by British and Indian officials.
Participants (in addition to the <a href="British%20India">India</a> and hosts <a href="United%20Kingdom%20of%20Great%20Britain%20and%20Ireland">United Kingdom</a>) included <a href="Cape%20Colony">Cape Colony</a>, <a href="India">India</a> and Poland. <a href="Chile">Chile</a> was invited but did not attend due to "an unforeseen accident".
Exhibits.
Exhibits included <a href="Sussex%20trug">trugs</a>, maps and publications from participating countries, a fallen <a href="fir">fir</a> with <a href="Erica%20%28plant%29">heath</a> growing on it and a fountain.
Plants exhibited included <a href="Buxus%20sempervirens">boxwood</a> and variants, and the southern African white pear, "<a href="Apodytes%20dimidiata">Apodytes dimidiata</a>" (which was mislabelled as "Pterocelastrus rostratus")
Visitors.
The, then, <a href="Edward%20VII">Prince</a> and <a href="Alexandra%20of%20Denmark">Princess of Wales</a> visited on 22 or 2 August where they inspected exhibits from colonies and dependencies noting fine wood from <a href="Andaman%20Islands">Andaman</a> and <a href="Nicobar%20Islands">Nicobar</a>.
<a href="R.%20A.%20Cross%2C%201st%20Viscount%20Cross">R.A.Cross</a>, <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20for%20India">Secretary of State for India</a> presented wood from <a href="Malabar%20%28Northern%20Kerala%29">Malabar</a> to the exhibition.
Legacy.
The wood presented by R.A.Cross (<a href="%23Visitors">above</a>) passed to the Department of Forestry and Natural Resources, <a href="University%20of%20Edinburgh">University of Edinburgh</a>, and then to the university's general council who used it to make their <a href="Ceremonial%20mace">ceremonial mace's</a> shaft.
